case_title: Messrs CARVAN ENTERPRISES through Manager vs CENTRAL BOARD OF REVENUE through Second Secretary and 3 others
respondant: CENTRAL BOARD OF REVENUE through Second Secretary
complaint_summary: Petitioner filed a complaint seeking cancellation of order-in-original and order-in-appeal passed by Respondents Nos.2 and 4, alleging procedural violations and lack of opportunity to be heard.
investigation_summary: Federal Tax Ombudsman (FTO) accepted the complaint and recommended cancellation of the impugned orders due to procedural lapses and non-compliance with statutory timelines.

judgment_summary.fto_order_finality: Order attained finality as no representation was filed under Section 32 of the Establishment of the Office of Federal Tax Ombudsman Ordinance, 2000.
judgment_summary.fto_recommendation_scope: No recommendation for reopening the case for de novo consideration.
legal_deficiencies: Violation of Audi Alteram Partem principle.
Failure to meet requirements of Section 45A of Sales Tax Act, 1990.
judgment_summary.court_order: The court set aside the impugned order dated 2006-07-28, citing procedural violations under Section 45A of the Sales Tax Act, 1990, and remanded the matter to the Federal Board of Revenue (FBR) to issue notice, hear the petitioner, and pass an appropriate order in accordance with law.

Decision_or_verdict: Petition allowed; matter remanded to FBR for re-adjudication in accordance with law.
legal_arguments: Violation of Section 45A of the Sales Tax Act, 1990 regarding notice and opportunity to be heard.
Procedural lapses in adjudication and appeal timelines under Section 36(3) and Section 45-B(2) of the Sales Tax Act, 1990.

legal_issues.section_36_3_violation: Adjudication order passed after 10 months instead of within 90 days.
legal_issues.section_45_B_2_violation: Appeal decided after 7 months instead of within 90 days.
legal_issues.section_45_A_violation: No notice or hearing provided before reopening the case.

statutes: Establishment of the Office of Federal Tax Ombudsman Ordinance, 2000
key_issues: Non-compliance with statutory timelines for adjudication and appeal.
Violation of procedural rights under Section 45A of the Sales Tax Act, 1990.

maxims.Audi Alteram Partem: Right to be heard before a decision is made.

legal_terms.De Novo: Reconsideration of a matter from the beginning.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around procedural violations in tax adjudication and appeal processes. The petitioner challenged orders passed by tax authorities citing non-compliance with statutory timelines and lack of opportunity to be heard. The Federal Tax Ombudsman recommended cancellation of the impugned orders, which was not appropriately implemented. The court set aside the impugned order and remanded the matter to the Federal Board of Revenue for re-adjudication in compliance with legal requirements.
